coursePurpose: Work effectively in a group and independently to manage workload and meet regularly scheduled deadlines

Analyze complex economic events to identify and extract relevant information necessary to record technical accounting transactions with transparency and accuracy in accordance with U.S. Generally Accepted Accounting Principles
Demonstrate understanding of recent accounting and regulatory updates
Critically evaluate financial statement data and apply critical thinking and ethical reasoning to choose a course of action in various business contexts
Identify how principles of accounting illustrate or illuminate principles of the gospel and their application to personal journeys of faith in Jesus Christ
topicsCovered: Acquisition, disposal, and impairment of long-term assets
learningOutcomes: Apply the Marriott Values to class and team interactions to improve learning and the Junior Core experience for yourself and others
Apply financial accounting standards and concepts to various business situations
Use the FASB Accounting Standards Codification to understand and apply U.S. GAAP
Apply ethical considerations to financial reporting issues including understanding of relevant regulations related to sustainability disclosures
Demonstrate effective communication skills via class discussion and the ability to discuss subject matter in ad hoc discussions
Demonstrate the value of regular reflection to deepen understanding of financial accounting concepts and draw connections between observed world and principles of the gospel

requiredMaterials.title: Intermediate Accounting
requiredMaterials.billing: Billed directly to student account after add/drop deadline

requiredMaterials.title: Three Course Packets
requiredMaterials.contents: Pre-class study questions, in-class handouts, exam review preparation materials
requiredMaterials.distribution: First packet provided during Junior Core orientation on first day
requiredMaterials.billing: Billed directly to student account after add/drop deadline

requiredMaterials.title: Financial Calculator
requiredMaterials.alternatives: TI Ba II Plus or other financial calculator
requiredMaterials.restrictions: No programmable calculators, graphing calculators, smartphones, or phone apps for exams
requiredMaterials.note: Recommended to start semester with calculator to practice before exams

characteristicsOfSuccessfulStudents: Choose to be optimistic and grateful for the opportunity to learn
Create your own definition of success based on your input, not outcomes
Focus on learning and helping others to learn
Develop a learning approach that works for you
Think critically about principles of accounting
Ask questions in a timely manner when you do not understand
Practice application of your understanding by doing problems before checking answers
Meet with your professor early and often in the semester if you are struggling
Limit or avoid working - recommend no more than 10 hours per week if working

learningReflections.description: Reflect on questions provided at end of each class and record thoughts in course packet
learningReflections.grading: Three Canvas quizzes during semester assess participation and insights gained
learningReflections.basis: Thoughtful completion of reflections, commitment to personal growth in BYU Marriott Values

preClassKnowledgeDemonstrations.description: Graded pre-class quizzes due prior to class
preClassKnowledgeDemonstrations.purpose: Ensure important information is understood and help formulate questions for class
preClassKnowledgeDemonstrations.collaboration: Individual work (INDIVIDUAL RED) - no AI, no note material from others
preClassKnowledgeDemonstrations.ungraded: Ungraded practice quizzes available before graded knowledge demonstration - can work with group on these
preClassKnowledgeDemonstrations.practiceExam: One practice exam in testing center before first midterm - full credit for completing on time
preClassKnowledgeDemonstrations.drops: Two pre-class quizzes can be dropped for unexpected absences, illness, computer issues
preClassKnowledgeDemonstrations.additionalDrop: One additional drop available by participating in research project

reviewQuizzes.description: Post-class quizzes to facilitate review of prior material
reviewQuizzes.availability: Available a few days following class coverage
reviewQuizzes.collaboration: After first attempt - open book, open notes, can discuss with classmates but submit own answers (INDIVIDUAL YELLOW)
reviewQuizzes.attempts: Generally four attempts with no loss of points
reviewQuizzes.drops: Only one automatically dropped - no additional drops

warenFinancialStatements.description: Compile financial statements for the Waren case (Systems Understanding Aid)
warenFinancialStatements.purpose: Helpful preparation for first mid-term exam
warenFinancialStatements.note: Waren case also used in Accounting Information Systems course

exams.dates: As indicated on overall Junior Core calendar
exams.coverage: Material from reading, classroom discussions, quizzes, and all assignments
exams.format: Specific details provided prior to each exam
exams.perspective: Exams are important but only one measure at one point in time

professionalism.evidencedIn: Class preparation and demeanor, class interactions and participation, communication with peers and faculty, contributions to positive class culture, emotional intelligence in all interactions, effective group engagement
